channel.title: What is an OS programmed in?
channel.description: If I were thinking about creating an OS along with building a computer for my senior project, would that be taking it to far?

Might help you out a bit.

item.title: What is an OS programmed in?
item.dc:creator: @ninja_nub ninja nub
item.description:
@ninja_nub wrote:

[quote=“ThAt0n36Uy, post:7, topic:200381”]You might would be better off developing a very compact flavor of Linux. Similar to Puppy Linux, or DSL. That would get you some good credit, as well as something to put in a job application. Building a computer is nothing at all, an afternoon putting things where they go.

Though, developing a Linux Distribution lasts, and gives you great knowledge of Linux. Puppy Linux and DSL have already accomplished a great deal in size. You might could look at making a more user friendly distro. Or maybe use linux to host a website, devoted to Linux. Something like that would easily get you a good score. The ignorant old bags in High School really can’t appreciate some of the work that goes into managing a successful website. So they’ll just pass you without much more than a glance and nod.[/quote]

Yeah, DSL (Damn small Linux) is excellent to use. Powerful and small… I suggest to do something like it.

Read full topic
item.source: What is an OS programmed in?

item.title: What is an OS programmed in?
item.dc:creator: @ThAt0n36Uy Elijah
item.description:
@ThAt0n36Uy wrote:

You might would be better off developing a very compact flavor of Linux. Similar to Puppy Linux, or DSL. That would get you some good credit, as well as something to put in a job application. Building a computer is nothing at all, an afternoon putting things where they go.

Though, developing a Linux Distribution lasts, and gives you great knowledge of Linux. Puppy Linux and DSL have already accomplished a great deal in size. You might could look at making a more user friendly distro. Or maybe use linux to host a website, devoted to Linux. Something like that would easily get you a good score. The ignorant old bags in High School really can’t appreciate some of the work that goes into managing a successful website. So they’ll just pass you without much more than a glance and nod.

Read full topic
item.source: What is an OS programmed in?

item.title: What is an OS programmed in?
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

All operating system kernels are written in C, but the boot loader and initial startup is done in assembly. After you have a base operating system running, you could add support for things like the Java VM, which would allow you to write high level applications in a language running in the JVM. Of course, it would be a ridiculous amount of work before you would be even close to implementing anything like a virtual machine.

If you’re into .NET, take a look at Singularity, an OS written almost entirely in C#.

Read full topic
item.source: What is an OS programmed in?

item.title: What is an OS programmed in?
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

Good luck with the OS, rifk.

Anyway http://mikeos.berlios.de/ would be really useful as a learning tool.

MikeOS isn't intended to be a general-purpose OS; it is designed as a learning tool to demonstrate how simple operating systems work. If you want to delve into OS development and learn x86 assembly language, MikeOS is a good place to start -- the code is simple, we have thorough documentation, and we're happy to include new features.

Read full topic
